column2:
Important background: I'm an automobile enthusiast and live in a dense urban environment. 95% of the time while I'm driving I entirely disregard my speedometer. This would not change even with it being in my line of sight. 

Due to the frequency of changing conditions entering my field of view and areas I'm monitoring (pedestrians, potential pedestrians at each intersection, other cars changing lanes, animals, etc), I don't judge my speed using a speedometer, but a sense of how fast I'm moving. 

I'd love to pretend I can tell you how quickly objects wiz past me, but it's actually that I've come to learn my car. It's fairly easy even for a regular driver to learn the sound and feel of a car going a certain speed. It does have something to do with how fast things wiz past you, but only when in combination. 

I've observed both significant others, family members, and friends drive in the same manner. I'm certain that in a new car one would need to rely on a speedometer more often, but other than highway useage, it's not even in the the top 5 most critical things attention would be on in a city environment.

A heads-up that just keeps you driver focused on the road is far better.
